executive_summary: Bowling centers handily recovered from COVID-19 closures but experienced extreme revenue volatility over the last few years. Revenue plummeted because of business closures and shelter-in-place orders in 2020, then spiked in 2021 thanks to rising disposable income propping up discretionary spending. Profit was as volatile as revenue but stabilized post-pandemic with the assistance of government aid. In line with the unprecedented losses experienced in 2020, industry-wide revenue has been falling at a CAGR of 5.2% over the past five years and is expected to total $3.8 billion in 2024, when revenue will contract an estimated 2.2%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: To attract families and young adults, bowling centers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: To attract families and young adults, bowling centers have expanded their products and services, transforming their businesses into entertainment centers. These facilities feature various attractions, from laser tag to arcade games. Many centers have updated lanes and begun incorporating state-of-the-art video, AR and music to gamify and modernize the bowling experience.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consolidation will allow bowling centers to take
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consolidation will allow bowling centers to take advantage of economies of scale to motivate profit growth and stability. Since a dense populous, urban or suburban, in either warm or cold climates has been a primary factor in location choice, increased urbanization trends will benefit entertainment-focused bowling centers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Looking down the road, growth in disposable income
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Looking down the road, growth in disposable income is expected to support demand for bowling and other recreational expenditures over the next five years. Increasingly accessible entertainment options will continually challenge bowling centers' revenue. With remote gaming and VR entertainment options experiencing continued growth in popularity and decreasing prices, consumer interest in bowling will continue to wane. Revenue is forecast to fall at a CAGR of 1.4% through 2029 to total $3.5 billion.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The outbreak of COVID-19 brought on a sizable drop
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The outbreak of COVID-19 brought on a sizable drop in revenue in 2020, because of business closures and shelter-in-place orders keeping consumers at home. Rising acceptance and use of these in-home entertainment options is a particularly threatening development spurred by COVID-19 that will be challenging to compete with. This catalyst inspired the increased adoption of innovative products and tech (AR, video-enhanced bowling lanes) at bowling centers to attract younger and casual bowlers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: As the new open-play consumer expects innovative
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the new open-play consumer expects innovative gaming and ancillary services, facilities will need to be of large scale, with a larger geographic footprint. Bowling centers that can invest in upgrading facilities have an advantage over more rundown centers with outdated décor. Growth by acquisition and consolidation has become increasingly common. This grows economies of scale purchasing power of enterprises and the ability to spread costs over a larger customer base.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry primarily operate bowling centers. Establishments often sell food and beverages.

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: Competition throws a spare, and smaller bowling centers fall. Large bowling enterprises with various entertainment options lure customers from traditional establishments, challenging the bottom line and forcing exit.

Competition from out-market entertainment rolls along. Virtual and real-life entertainment and sports options appeal to a young demographic. Exclusion from the Olympics demonstrates that bowling is not gaining a young audience.

Centers no longer struggle with a split personality. Centers are differentiating; some remain focused on league players and others intrigue open bowlers with expanding entertainment services delivered with engaging VR, AR audio and video technologies.

COVID-19 led to volatility and consolidation. Revenue loss was massive during COVID-19, but it spurred continued consolidation where remaining larger establishments would better benefit from economies of scale and scope.

Multiple entertainment lanes are vital for major player Bowlero Corporation. With a large share of industry revenue from bowling, brand recognition and a range of services characterize the prominent enterprises.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Rural consumers reside in non-urban, low-populated areas. These individuals share a strong sense of community, often expressed through spending time together, supporting local businesses, bowling and being part of a league.
These consumers are bowlers residing in densely populated metropolitan areas. Urban open-play bowlers account for a more significant share of revenue than league-play bowlers.

Open-play bowlers in suburban neighborhoods account for the lion's share of revenue, playing casually and spontaneously. In suburban markets, open-play bowling generates a more significant share of revenue than league play.

Rural consumers reside in non-urban, low-populated areas. These individuals share a strong sense of community, often expressed through spending time together, supporting local businesses, bowling and being part of a league.
These consumers are bowlers residing in densely populated metropolitan areas. Urban league-play bowlers account for a lower share of revenue compared to open-play bowlers.
League bowlers compete in organized teams, typically committing to at least one game a week. In suburban markets, league-play bowling generates a lower share of revenue compared to open-play bowling.

products_and_services.product_description: Bowling Remains the Central Activity. The main draw and revenue source remains bowling, representing more than half the revenue for the bowling center.

Raise a Glass to Food and Drink Sales. As the industry has evolved into a mixed-use entertainment industry, food and drink services have become an increasingly essential source of revenue for the industry.

Nonbowling Games, Activities and Services Give Revenue an Extra Boost. Nonbowling games and activities (i.e., ancillary gaming services, arcades, laser tag, miniature golf and bumper cars) are anticipated to be a significant revenue source for the younger crowd.
Other products and services include merchandise sales from pro shops, social event planning and coordination services and lotteries.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Trends in per capita disposable income are positively correlated with changes in revenue. When individuals have a greater amount of disposable income, they are more likely to spend on discretionary activities, like bowling.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has the largest share of bowling centers, with just over a quarter share of US establishments. Four of the top five states with the largest share of establishments, Michigan, Wisconsin and Illinois, are part of the Great Lakes region.
The Southeast region has a shortfall of bowling center locations compared to its population share.

The Mid-Atlantic Region's share of establishments keeps pace with its population share. New York has the largest share of establishments among the states contributing a significant percentage of the Mid-Atlantic's location share.
The West region has a shortfall of bowling center locations compared to its population share.
The Southwest region has a shortfall of bowling center locations compared to its population share.
The Rocky Mountain region has a more significant location share than population share, likely due to the scattered population density based on diverse geography.
New England, a densely populated region, has a more significant location share than population share.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Alcohol sales and other licensing and regulations
regulations_points.regulation_description: Bowling centers are subject to many governmental authorities and rules (alcoholic beverage control, health, safety and fire codes.) If alcohol is sold, licenses are typically renewed annually and may be revoked or suspended at any time. Alcoholic regulations concern the minimum age of patrons and employees, hours of operation, advertising, wholesale purchasing, inventory control and handling and storing and dispensing alcoholic drinks.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Zoning, employee, development and patron regulations
regulations_points.regulation_description: Bowling centers must comply with required town planning, zoning and development regulations. They are subject to the Fair Labor Standards Act, which governs minimum wage, overtime and working conditions, and the Americans with Disabilities Act, which mandates wheelchair accessibility and other assistive equipment.

regulations_points.regulation_title: United States Bowling Congress Equipment and Specifications Committee (USBC)
regulations_points.regulation_description: This national body for bowling provides standardized rules and regulations for members. The committee has concluded the removal of balance holes on bowling balls, effective August 1, 2018. Bowlers could continue using their current bowling balls with balance holes until August 1, 2020, given that the ball complied with current static weight specifications.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition throws a spare, and smaller bowling centers fall
basis_points.basis_description: Large bowling enterprises with various entertainment options lure customers from traditional establishments, challenging the bottom line and forcing exit.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition from out-market entertainment rolls along
basis_points.basis_description: Virtual and real-life entertainment and sports options appeal to a young demographic. Exclusion from the Olympics demonstrates that bowling is not gaining a young audience.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Multiple Entertainment Lanes Will Hasten Concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: The level of concentration within the industry has increased in recent years. The merger between AMF Bowling Worldwide and Strike Holdings LLC and the subsequent acquisition of Brunswick's bowling centers (now known as Bowlero Corporation) has boosted the industry's market share concentration during the period.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Out-of-Market Options Bring Price Competition and Consolidation
concentration_points.concentration_description: Smaller establishments have to compete with larger bowling entertainment centers with many activities, in addition to other entertainment center offerings and at-home entertainment options. As technology enhances other entertainment center games and sports options, small traditional bowling centers will face stiffer price competition and some may be forced to exit, thereby increasing market concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases represent the third-largest expense and have remained relatively stable over the last five years. The sales cost includes food, beverages, alcohol and merchandise. The supplies costs include all items required to operate a bowling center, including office supplies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Open-Play or League-Play Customers Impact Purchases Cost
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: According to the BPAA, centers with more league-play customers experienced a lower cost of sales per lane than those with more open-play customers. Larger entertainment bowling centers have catered to open-play bowlers offering non-bowling games and entertainment, which can bump purchase cost as a share of revenue.

In addition to taking the biggest piece of the pie, wages have increased moderately. Skilled workers are needed to repair systems and infrastructure, while part-time workers can defray another wage cost. Large bowling centers will not invest in robot AI-powered bartenders until costs decrease, though their presence in the industry is slowly growing.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Large or small in bowling center size, marketing is essential
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Marketing expenditure, which includes advertising and promotional expenses, is anticipated to account for a little less than it did in 2019. Bowling centers invest in TV and radio commercials, posters and small billboard placements to generate buzz for special offers. Many centers also use social media platforms to build a sizeable customer base. On average, bowling centers with primarily league-play customers have lower advertising costs than those catering to open-play bowlers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Moderate capital intensity does not pose a significant barrier to entry. Still, it may pose a barrier as larger enterprises adopt new sophisticated systems, raising the quality and variety of services bowlers expect.

volatility_points.volatility_title: COVID-19 strikes, sending revenue into the gutter
volatility_points.volatility_description: Amid COVID-19, many state governments imposed the closure of nonessential businesses. Bowling centers were required to shutter temporarily and experienced a crippling loss of revenue. The reduced unemployment rate, an uptick in consumer spending and per capita disposable income boosted individuals' discretionary expenditures post-COVID-19 and enabled significant revenue growth.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Falling per capita disposable income impacts discretionary spending
volatility_points.volatility_description: Discretionary expenditures will be more volatile when the economy experiences inflation, and individuals face changes in employment and income. An expected drop in per capita disposable income growth due to inflationary pressure and increases in the unemployment rate are expected to turn revenue growth negative in 2024. Expected decreases in time spent on leisure and sports, lower consumer spending levels and rising preference for video games will add to high volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Technology and augmented reality really light up the lanes
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Crunchy Tech's "Unreal Bowling" is an interactive bowling experience where the lane comes to life with graphics and audio. From individuals' smartphones, the bowler can change the music and mood and personalize graphics for unique themes, with audible scoring and animations that fly down the lane following the ball. The entertaining and party atmosphere will attract the open-play bowlers, the source of the majority of revenue and a younger demographic.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: High-end food products and cocktails innovations get the party started
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: For bowling entertainment centers, food and cocktail innovations bring a sophisticated and party atmosphere for the open-play market. Craft beers, innovative cocktails and introducing innovative foods will entice evening patronage and attract local restaurants and bars for evening entertainment.

FAQs.question: How well does your company market to consumers with limited leisure time?
Rising disposable income drove growth in discretionary spending, contributing to revenue gains. Is your revenue sensitive to changes in discretionary spending?
FAQs.answer: The Bowling Centers industry provides discretionary entertainment services. Revenue depends heavily on how much consumers can save for non-essential spending.

FAQs.question: If your company benefits from population density, are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: A majority of industry revenue is derived from bowling alleys located in urban and suburban locations. Operators located near residential areas can better compete with the convenience of home and other alternative entertainment options.

FAQs.question: How does your company use location to add value and offer unique products and services to your consumers?
FAQs.answer: Bowling centers located in densely populated urban areas benefit from offering various nonbowling entertainment sources at their establishments, like arcades, laser tag, full-service restaurants and bar and lounge settings.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored lowering wage costs through part-time labor and automation via point-of-sale systems?
FAQs.answer: The bowling process is largely automated or handled by the customer, which tempers labor costs to a certain degree. Employees generally work on a part-time basis and serve a myriad of functions from cleaning and maintenance to working cash registers and organizing events and parties.

FAQs.question: Have you established a strong internet presence through social media platforms to capture a larger audience?
FAQs.answer: A majority of operators report using sites such as Facebook and Twitter to promote their centers. Bowling centers also invest in television and radio commercials, along with poster and small billboard placements, to generate buzz for special offers.

FAQs.question: Are you up-to-date with legislative and regulatory changes that may allow your company to expand into new markets?
FAQs.answer: Each center is required to obtain a license from a state authority and, in certain locations, from county and municipal authorities, if it sells alcoholic beverages on the premises. Bowling centers must comply with required town planning, zoning and development regulations in relation to the location and building of amusement arcades.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company require federal and state approval for capital improvements?
Is your company's profit margin in step with major competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profitability varies widely in the Bowling Centers industry and is largely dependent on enterprise size. Larger entertainment bowling centers tend to experience wider margins than traditional centers.

FAQs.question: Does your company have to purchase new equipment on an annual basis?
FAQs.answer: Bowling balls and shoes do not generally need to be replaced on an annual basis. More consistent purchase costs for operators include spending on food, beverages, alcohol and merchandise.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your revenue goes toward wages?
How do you attract flexible employees for seasons of peak demand?
FAQs.answer: Given the weekly and seasonal nature of demand, access to a flexible, casual workforce helps operators contain wage costs. The bowling process is largely automated or handled by the customer, which tempers labor costs to a certain degree.

FAQs.question: What maintenance costs are involved for your bowling center? Is your center considered suitable for professional tournaments?
FAQs.answer: Carrying out all necessary maintenance to keep facilities in good condition. The highly mechanized nature of most bowling centers requires a good deal of electricity to maintain operations. Maintaining clean facilities and making routine equipment upgrades are necessary to generate repeat customers.

FAQs.question: Has your company measured the revenue from league bowlers versus casual, high-income bowlers? Which of your offerings appeals to this cohort?
FAQs.answer: League bowlers, which once represented the major market for bowling centers, now account for a shrinking share of bowling revenue. The market for bowling centers has shifted toward casual, higher-income consumers. Catering to this market, rather than traditional league players, taps into the industry's current source of demand.

FAQs.question: Demand for video games has grown, increasing competition for alternative leisure time activities, such as bowling. What offerings do you have in place that compete with video games? What strategies are in play to win leisure time hours from consumers?
FAQs.answer: Demand for video games has grown rapidly, increasing competition for alternative leisure time activities, like bowling.

FAQs.question: What strategies have you implemented to maintain your consumer base? How has your company cut costs to maintain profit due to decreased leisure time?
FAQs.answer: In general, an increase in available leisure time for bowling patrons will encourage demand for bowling center services. If this free time is gained because of unemployment, leisure time does not benefit the industry as consumers are less likely to spend money on discretionary entertainment.

FAQs.question: What strategies have you implemented to attract high-income customers? How can your company improve its offerings to appeal to high-income earners?
FAQs.answer: Increased per capita disposable income leads to greater expenditure on leisure activities, including trips to bowling centers. Consumers in households that earn more than $100,000 a year are the largest market for bowling centers.
